curriculumTitle: Essential Chemistry: A 40-Module High School Lab Series (Texas TRIO Edition)
overview: A comprehensive, hands-on chemistry curriculum designed for Texas High School students (grades 9-12). This guide structures 40 short-format modules (20-40 minutes each) focusing on foundational concepts ranging from properties of matter to chemical kinetics, stoichiometry, and organic chemistry. Explicitly designed for compliance with Texas TEKS (Chapter 112.35) and Federal TRIO (Upward Bound/UBMS) grant regulations (34 CFR Part 645), emphasizing low-cost consumables (EDGAR 2 CFR 200.453) and high-engagement inquiry.
prerequisites: Completion of Algebra I; enrolled in or completed 9th grade Integrated Physics and Chemistry (IPC) or Biology.

fieldTrips.name: Perot Museum of Nature and Science - Lyda Hill Gems and Minerals Hall
fieldTrips.description: Guided exploration of crystallography and mineral chemistry.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Connects to Modules 1, 10, and 29 regarding density, crystallization, and chemical composition.

fieldTrips.name: Bureau of Engraving and Printing - Western Currency Facility
fieldTrips.description: Tour of the ink chemistry and paper fiber analysis labs used in currency production.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Direct application of Module 6 (Chromatography) and Module 33 (Corrosion/Materials Science).

fieldTrips.name: Trinity River Authority - Central Regional Wastewater System
fieldTrips.description: Industrial scale water filtration and chemical treatment processes.

fieldTrips.name: University of Texas at Arlington - Shimadzu Center for Advanced Analytical Chemistry
fieldTrips.description: Tour of advanced spectroscopy and chromatography instrumentation labs.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Provides college pathway exposure for Modules 7 (Flame Tests) and 19 (Isotopes/Mass).

activities.title: Module 1: Liquid Layers - Mastering Density
activities.description: Students investigate the physical property of density by creating a multi-layered density column using household liquids with varying sugar concentrations.
learningObjectives: Define density as mass per unit volume.
Observe how liquids of different densities interact without mixing immediately.
Calculate density based on mass and volume measurements.
teks: 112.35(c)(4)(B): Investigate and describe physical and chemical properties of matter.
texasStemStandards: STEM Content Knowledge: Application of science concepts.
Employability Skills: Critical thinking and problem solving.

brief: Prepare sugar solutions of varying concentrations (0%, 20%, 40%, 60%).
Dye each concentration a different color.
Guide students to layer liquids slowly.
detailed: Pre-Lab Prep: Create four stock solutions. Cup 1: Water only + Red. Cup 2: Water + 1 tbsp sugar + Yellow. Cup 3: Water + 2 tbsp sugar + Green. Cup 4: Water + 3 tbsp sugar + Blue.
Introduction: Discuss D=m/v. Ask why oil floats on water.
Activity: Have students attempt to stack the colors, heaviest (Blue) on bottom.
Review: Discuss why the layers separate.

brief: Use the pipette to slowly add the heaviest liquid first.
Layer the lighter liquids on top gently.
detailed: Step 1: Observe the four colored solutions.
Step 2: Add 5mL of the Blue solution to your cylinder.
Step 3: Carefully draw up the Green solution.
Step 4: Tilt the cylinder and drip the Green liquid down the side slowly.
Step 5: Repeat with Yellow, then Red.

trioCompliance.justification: Fulfills mandatory curriculum requirement for instruction in laboratory science.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(1): Academic instruction in laboratory science.
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(b)(1): Exposure to a rigorous curriculum.
edgarCitations: 2 CFR 200.453: Materials and supplies costs, including costs of computing devices.

activities.title: Module 2: Foaming Fury - Catalysts in Action
activities.description: A rapid decomposition reaction activity using 'Elephant Toothpaste' to demonstrate exothermic reactions and catalysts.
learningObjectives: Understand the role of a catalyst.
teks: 112.35(c)(11)(C): Classify reactions as exothermic or endothermic.

detailed: Activity: Students mix peroxide and soap, then add yeast solution.

brief: Pour peroxide and soap into bottle.
detailed: Step 2: Mix yeast with warm water in a cup.
Step 3: Pour 1/2 cup Hydrogen Peroxide into the bottle with a squirt of soap.
Step 4: Pour yeast mixture into the bottle.

trioCompliance.justification: Hands-on research and lab science exposure.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b): Services to improve math and science literacy.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Chemical Engineering

activities.title: Module 3: The Color of Chemistry - Acids and Bases
activities.description: Students create a natural pH indicator using red cabbage juice to test household substances.
learningObjectives: Use an indicator to determine pH.

brief: Set up stations with unknown liquids.
Instruct students to match colors to pH chart.
detailed: Prep: Boil cabbage to get purple water.
Activity: Students add indicator to unknowns. Red=Acid, Green=Base.
Analysis: Arrange from acidic to basic.
Step 2: Add 2mL cabbage juice to each.
Step 4: Rank the cups by pH.

trioCompliance.justification: Core chemistry competency using cost-effective materials.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(1): Academic instruction in laboratory science.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science
Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Sciences

activities.title: Module 4: Gas Laws - The Crushing Can
activities.description: Demonstration of Charles's Law and atmospheric pressure by imploding a soda can.
learningObjectives: Demonstrate relationship between temperature and volume.

brief: Heat water in can until steaming.
detailed: Theory: Gas expands when heated, contracts when cooled.
Action: Rapidly invert the can into water to seal it.
Discussion: Atmospheric pressure crushed the vacuum.
Step 2: Heat 1 tbsp water in can.
Step 3: When steaming, grab with tongs.
Step 4: Flip upside down into ice water immediately.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b): Services to improve math and science literacy.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering
Associate of Applied Science in HVAC Technology

activities.title: Module 5: Slime Time - Introduction to Polymers
activities.description: Synthesis of cross-linked polymer using PVA glue and borate ions.

detailed: Concept: Glue molecules are chains; Borax connects them.
Activity: Mix components, observe viscosity change.
Cleanup: Use bags, do not sink.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(1): Academic instruction in laboratory science.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Materials Science

activities.title: Module 6: Chromatographic Colors - Separation Science
activities.description: Students use paper chromatography to separate the pigments in black ink, demonstrating solubility and molecular polarity.
teks: 112.35(c)(4)(D): Classify matter as pure substances or mixtures.

brief: Mark a dot of ink 2cm from bottom.
Suspend in water (water level below ink).
detailed: Setup: Ensure the ink dot does not touch water directly.
Analysis: Calculate Rf values (distance traveled by pigment / distance by water).

brief: Dip bottom of paper in water.
detailed: Step 1: Cut a strip of filter paper.
Step 2: Draw a heavy dot of black ink 2cm from the bottom.
Step 3: Hang the paper in a cup with a little water at the bottom.
Step 4: Do not let the dot touch the water directly.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(1): Academic instruction in laboratory science.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Forensic Science

activities.title: Module 7: Flame Tests - Atomic Fingerprints
activities.description: Students burn various salt solutions to observe characteristic flame colors, identifying elements based on electron energy transitions.

brief: Have students hold splint in flame.
detailed: Theory: Electrons jump to excited state, release photons falling back.
Step 3: Place damp end into the blue part of the flame.
Step 4: Note the immediate color change.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b): Services to improve math and science literacy.

activities.title: Module 8: Bag of Change - Conservation of Mass
activities.description: Students conduct a reaction between baking soda and vinegar inside a sealed Ziploc bag to prove mass is conserved.
learningObjectives: Verify Law of Conservation of Mass.

detailed: Setup: Put vinegar in bag, baking soda in a small cup *inside* bag.
Action: Seal bag, tip cup to mix.
Check: Mass should stay same despite bag inflating.
Step 2: Float cup of soda in vinegar.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(1): Academic instruction in laboratory science.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Manufacturing Engineering
Associate of Science in Quality Assurance

activities.title: Module 9: Hot and Cold - Energy in Reactions
activities.description: Comparing endothermic and exothermic reactions using ammonium nitrate (cold packs) and calcium chloride (damp rid).

detailed: Have students graph the temp change.
Step 2: Add 1 spoon of white solid.
Step 4: Is it hot or cold?

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b): Services to improve math and science literacy.

collegePathways: Bachelor of Science in Chemical Engineering

activities.title: Module 10: Hot Ice - Supersaturated Solutions
activities.description: Students crystallize sodium acetate from a supersaturated solution to create rapid 'hot ice' sculptures.

detailed: Prep: This is tricky. Solution must be very pure.
Action: Pour cooled liquid onto a crystal; it instantly solidifies and releases heat.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402E(b): Services to improve math and science literacy.

activities.title: Module 11: Drop by Drop - Intro to Titration
activities.description: Simple acid-base neutralization counting drops of base to neutralize an acid with indicator.

brief: Setup acid in cup with indicator.

activities.title: Module 12: Lemon Power - Electrochemistry
activities.description: Building a battery using lemons, copper coins, and zinc nails to power an LED.

detailed: Need multiple lemons in series to light LED.

brief: Push nail and penny into lemon.

Step 4: Chain lemons to increase voltage.

activities.title: Module 13: Glow Stick Kinetics
activities.description: Investigating how temperature affects the rate of the chemical reaction in glow sticks.

brief: Place one in hot, one in cold.

detailed: Step 2: Put one in ice, one in hot water, one in air.

activities.title: Module 14: Crushed vs Whole - Surface Area
activities.description: Comparing reaction rates of whole vs crushed Alka-Seltzer tablets in water.
learningObjectives: Relate surface area to reaction rate.

detailed: Crushed tablet exposes more particles for collisions, reacting faster.
Step 1: Prepare two cups of water.
Step 2: Drop whole tablet in A. Time it.
Step 3: Drop powder in B. Time it.

heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b)(1): Academic instruction in laboratory science.

activities.title: Module 15: Precipitate Art - Double Replacement

Step 2: Place black paper on tray.
Step 3: Drip A then B on top.

activities.title: Module 16: The Rust Race - Oxidation
activities.description: Accelerating the rusting of steel wool using vinegar and bleach to study oxidation-reduction.

detailed: Bleach is strong oxidizer -> Rapid rust.
Step 1: Dip wool in vinegar 1 min.
Step 3: Place in jar with dilute bleach.
Step 4: Watch it turn orange instantly.

activities.description: Using a 9V battery and pencils to split water into Hydrogen and Oxygen gas.

detailed: Hydrogen at cathode (more bubbles), Oxygen at anode.
Step 2: Touch battery terminals with erasers.
Step 4: Note which side bubbles more (H2).

activities.description: Using milk, food coloring, and dish soap to visualize surface tension and polarity.

detailed: Soap breaks surface tension and interacts with fats, causing swirling.
Step 3: Soap touch -> Explosion of color.

activities.title: Module 30: The Pineapple Problem - Enzymes

brief: Add fresh fruit to one, canned to other.
detailed: Fresh has active enzyme -> Eats protein -> Liquid Jello. Canned is cooked -> Denatured -> Solid Jello.
